{{Short description|Marvel Comics fictional character}} {{For|the Marvel Cinematic Universe version of the character|Claire Temple (Marvel Cinematic Universe)}} {{Infobox comics character | character_name = Claire Temple | image = Claire Temple (August 1972).jpg | caption = Claire meets Luke Cage, from ''Luke Cage, Hero for Hire'' #2 (August 1972) | publisher = [[Marvel Comics]] | debut = ''[[Luke Cage, Hero for Hire]]'' #2 (August 1972) | creators = [[Archie Goodwin (comics)|Archie Goodwin]]
[[George Tuska]] | alliances = [[Heroes for Hire]] | partners = | supports = [[Luke Cage]] | aliases = | powers = Doctor | cat = | subcat = | hero = | villain = | sortkey = | addcharcat# = }} '''Claire Temple''' is a fictional character appearing in [[American comic book]]s published by [[Marvel Comics]]. She is primarily affiliated with the [[superhero]] [[Luke Cage]] and is one of his early love interests. Starting in 2015, [[Claire Temple (Marvel Cinematic Universe)|a version of the character]], portrayed by [[Rosario Dawson]], has appeared in multiple episodes of the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]] [[streaming television]] series, such as the first two seasons of ''[[Daredevil (TV series)|Daredevil]]'', an episode of the first season of ''[[Jessica Jones (TV series)|Jessica Jones]]'', ''[[Luke Cage (TV series)|Luke Cage]]'', the first season of ''[[Iron Fist (TV series)|Iron Fist]]'' and ''[[The Defenders (miniseries)|The Defenders]]''. She is a composite of Claire and the comic character [[Night Nurse (comics)|Night Nurse]]. ==Publication history== Claire Temple first appeared in ''[[Luke Cage, Hero for Hire]]'' #2 and was created by [[Archie Goodwin (comics)|Archie Goodwin]] and [[George Tuska]]. The character of African-American superhero Luke Cage was created shortly after [[Blaxploitation]] films emerged as a popular new genre.{{cite journal |last=Callahan |first=Timothy |date=December 2010 |title=Power Man and Iron Fist |journal=[[Back Issue!]] |issue=45 |pages=3–11 |publisher=[[TwoMorrows Publishing]]}} ==Fictional character biography== ===''Luke Cage''=== Luke Cage meets Dr. Claire Temple, who works with Dr. Noah Burstein at his 42nd Street storefront clinic.{{Cite comic | writer=[[Archie Goodwin (comics)|Goodwin, Archie]] | penciller=[[George Tuska|Tuska, George]] | inker=[[Billy Graham (comics)|Graham, Billy]] | letterer=[[John Costanza|Costanza, John]] | editor=[[Stan Lee|Lee, Stan]] | story=Vengeance is Mine! | title=[[Luke Cage, Hero for Hire]] | volume=1 | issue=2 | date=August 1972 | publisher=[[Marvel Comics]] | location=[[New York, NY]] }} Cage has been shot by hitmen sent by the criminal [[Diamondback (Willis Stryker)|Diamondback]], and Claire is surprised to find him only bruised by the bullets. She is subsequently kidnapped by Diamondback, who Cage discovers is his old friend Willis Stryker, the man who had framed Cage for the crime that sent him to prison. Cage frees Claire but Diamondback is killed by one of his own weapons. Claire corroborates Cage's story with the police,{{cite comic|date=October 1972|title=Luke Cage, Hero for Hire|story=Mark of the Mace!|volume=1|issue=3}} and the two become romantically involved.{{cite comic|date=December 1972|title=Luke Cage, Hero for Hire|story=Cry Fear...Cry Phantom!|volume=1|issue=4}} In 1973, Claire is surprised to see two grateful clients kissing Cage,{{cite comic|date=February 1973|title=Luke Cage, Hero for Hire|story=Knights and White Satin!|volume=1|issue=6}} but spending Christmas Eve together they are assaulted twice by the criminal Marley, whom Cage later subdues.{{cite comic|date=March 1973|title=Luke Cage, Hero for Hire|story=Jingle Bombs!|volume=1|issue=7}} As Claire and Cage continue dating,{{cite comic|date=April 1973|title=Luke Cage, Hero for Hire|story=Crescendo!|volume=1|issue=8}} Dr. Burstein—who is partially responsible for giving Cage his powers—continues to keep the secret from Claire (''[[Daily Bugle]]'' reporter Phil Fox) that Cage escaped from prison.{{cite comic|date=July 1973|title=Luke Cage, Hero for Hire|story=Where There's Life...!|volume=1|issue=11}} Cage is tortured by his complicity in the death of the criminal Lionfang, but Claire helps him to realize that the villain brought it upon himself.{{cite comic|date=September 1973|title=Luke Cage, Hero for Hire|story=The Claws of Lionfang|volume=1|issue=13}} Having discovered Cage's secret but unable to publish it, Fox teams up with Cage's prison guard nemesis Billy Bob Rackham to get revenge on Cage by kidnapping Claire.{{cite comic|date=October 1973|title=Luke Cage, Hero for Hire|story=Retribution!|volume=1|issue=14}} They kidnap the wrong woman, Fox is killed and the police find Claire holding the murder weapon. Cage creates a distraction to talk to Claire in custody, and she tells him that she now knows he is an escaped convict.{{cite comic|date=November 1973|title=Luke Cage, Hero for Hire|story=Retribution Part II|volume=1|issue=15}} Cage vows to find Fox's real killer. Rackham is revealed as the murderer, exonerating Claire, who is reunited with Cage.{{cite comic|date=December 1973|title=Luke Cage, Hero for Hire|story=Shake Hands with Stiletto!|volume=1|issue=16}} In the now-retitled ''[[Luke Cage, Power Man]]'' #18 (April 1974), Cage mourns his ex-girlfriend Reva Connors, who had been killed because of his rivalry with Willis Stryker.{{cite comic|date=April 1974|title=[[Luke Cage, Power Man]]|story=Havok on the High Iron!|volume=1|issue=18}} Despite Cage's belief that everyone who gets close to him dies, he and Claire decide to stay together. The relationship continues for years, with Claire often in danger because of her connection to Cage, and by 1976 his chosen profession has caused much conflict between them.{{cite comic|date=December 1976|story=Big Brother Wants You...Dead!|title=Power Man|volume=1|issue=38}} Cage is finally exonerated for the crime that originally put him in prison, but in the retitled ''[[Power Man and Iron Fist]]'' #50 (April 1978), Claire can no longer handle him constantly being in danger, and they separate.{{cite comic|date=April 1978|story=Freedom!|title=[[Power Man and Iron Fist]]|volume=1|issue=50}} Claire and Cage meet again in 1982, first at a crime scene,{{cite comic|date=February 1982|story=Slasher!|title=Power Man and Iron Fist|volume=1|issue=78}} and then when she treats the injuries of his girlfriend, Harmony Young.{{cite comic|date=August 1982|story=Revenge!|title=Power Man and Iron Fist|volume=1|issue=84}} Cage inadvertently insults Claire while she is treating his friend, [[Rafael Scarfe]], in 1983.{{cite comic|date=August 1983|story=Some Kind of Hero!|title=Power Man and Iron Fist|volume=1|issue=96}} Soon after, he decides to quit fighting crime because the local citizens seem ungrateful and derisive, but she convinces him how important his work is.{{cite comic|date=September 1983|story=The Coming of the She Beast!|title=Power Man and Iron Fist|volume=1|issue=97}} Later in the series, Claire treats an injured [[Iron Fist (comics)|Iron Fist]].{{cite comic|date=December 1983|story=Soul Games!|title=Power Man and Iron Fist|volume=1|issue=100}} ===Other appearances=== In ''[[Bill Foster (comics)|Black Goliath]]'' #1 (February 1976), Bill Foster/Black Goliath recalls his marriage to his college sweetheart Claire and their eventual separation.{{Cite comic | writer=[[Tony Isabella|Isabella, Tony]] | penciller=[[George Tuska|Tuska, George]] | inker=[[Vince Colletta|Colletta, Vince]] | colorist=Wolfman, Michele | letterer=Crespi, Dan and Irving Watanabe | coartists=[[Frank Giacoia|Giacoia, Frank]] (cover), [[Ron Wilson (comics)|Wilson, Ron]] (cover) | editor=[[Marv Wolfman|Wolfman, Marv]] | story= | title=[[Bill Foster (comics)|Black Goliath]] | volume=1 | issue=1 | date=February 1976 | publisher=Marvel Comics | location=New York, NY }} Claire treats a fully costumed [[Spider-Man]] following his fight with [[Man-Thing]] in ''[[Marvel Team-Up]]'' #123 (November 1982).{{cite comic|date=November 1982|story=Rivers of Blood|title=[[Marvel Team-Up]]|volume=1|issue=123}} As part of the ''[[All-New, All-Different Marvel]]'', Claire is a doctor who specializes in dealing with super-powered humans and bionic implants.{{cite comic |title=Captain America: Sam Wilson |issue=16 |date=December 2016}} She first appears in December 2015 in ''Captain America: Sam Wilson'' #4, where she treats [[Falcon (comics)|Captain America (Sam Wilson)]] when he is transformed into a werewolf by [[Karl Malus]]{{cite comic |title=Captain America: Sam Wilson |issue=4 |date=December 2015 }} and is later shown to be in regular contact with [[Misty Knight]].{{issue|date=January 2017}} After Rage had been arrested upon being accused of a pawn shop robbery done by [[Speed Demon (comics)|Speed Demon]] and [[Man Mountain Marko]] and is then beaten up in the penitentiary's Z Block by the super-powered prisoners which he previously apprehended, he was taken to the hospital where Sam is told by Claire Temple that Rage will not survive due to the extensive brain damage he sustained.''Captain America: Sam Wilson'' #2 During the ''[[Secret Empire (comics)|Secret Empire]]'' storyline, Claire Temple was in a Darkforce-covered Manhattan trying to tend to the ill civilians, as she tells the [[Defenders (comics)|Defenders]] that the hospital has limited medical supplies.''Secret Empire'' #2 ==In other media== ===Television=== {{main|Claire Temple (Marvel Cinematic Universe)}} *In the 2015 [[Netflix]] [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]] [[streaming television]] series ''[[Daredevil (TV series)|Daredevil]]'', [[Rosario Dawson]] plays nurse Claire Temple, an amalgamation of the comic character of the same name and [[Night Nurse (comics)|Night Nurse]].{{cite web |url=http://time.com/3774475/rosario-dawson-netflix-daredevil/ |title=Rosario Dawson on Being a Hero, Not a Love Interest, in Netflix's ''Daredevil'' |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |last=Dockterman |first=Eliana |date=April 8, 2015 |access-date=January 8, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702222808/http://time.com/3774475/rosario-dawson-netflix-daredevil |archive-date=July 2, 2015 |url-status=live}}{{cite web |url=http://www.denofgeek.us/tv/daredevil/245324/daredevil-netflix-series-marvel-universe-easter-eggs-and-comic-references-guide/page/0/1 |title=''Daredevil'' Netflix Series: Marvel Universe Easter Eggs and Comic References Guide |publisher=[[Den of Geek]] |first=Mike |last=Cecchini |date=November 14, 2015 |access-date=January 11, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/article/dawson-says-marvels-doing-something-fun-with-daredevils-claire-temple |title=Dawson Says 'Marvel's Doing Something Fun' with ''Daredevil''{{'s}} Claire Temple |work=[[Comic Book Resources]] |first=Scott |last=Huver |date=April 9, 2015 |access-date=January 11, 2016}} In the comics, Linda Carter of the 1970s series ''Night Nurse'' reappears in ''Daredevil'' vol. 2, #58 (May 2004), and becomes a character that superheroes—including [[Luke Cage]] and [[Iron Fist (comics)|Iron Fist]]—seek out for off the record medical care.{{cite web |url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/75092-daredevil-nurse-claire-temple-is-from-the-comics-but-shes-not-from-the-matt-murdoch-chronicles |title=''Daredevil'' Nurse Claire Temple Is From The Comics, But She's Not From The Matt Murdoch Chronicles |work=[[Bustle (magazine)|Bustle]] |first=Jefferson |last=Grubbs |date=April 10, 2014 |access-date=January 11, 2016}}{{cite web |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2015/07/29/daredevil-showrunner-on-the-one-thing-marvel-made-him-change-due-to-movie-plans |title=''Daredevil'' Showrunner On The One Thing Marvel Made Him Change Due To Movie Plans |last=Goldman |first=Eric |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=July 29, 2015 |access-date=July 29, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151211053321/http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/07/29/daredevil-showrunner-on-the-one-thing-marvel-made-him-change-due-to-movie-plans |archive-date=December 11, 2015 |url-status=live}}{{cite comic |title=[[Daredevil (Marvel Comics series)|Daredevil]] |volume=2 |issue=58 |date=May 2004}}{{cite comic |title=[[The Pulse (comics)|The Pulse]] |volume=1 |issue=9 |date=July 2005}}{{cite comic |title=[[Doctor Strange: The Oath]] |volume=1 |issue=1 |date=December 2006}} First appearing in the [[Daredevil (season 1)|Season 1]] episode "Cut Man", Claire is an emergency room nurse who helps the blind vigilante [[Daredevil (Marvel Comics character)|Matt Murdock]] after he is found badly injured in a dumpster.{{cite web |url=https://www.ew.com/recap/daredevil-season-1-episode-2 |title=TV Recaps - ''Daredevil'': 'Cut Man' |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |first=Kevin P. |last=Sullivan |date=April 10, 2015 |access-date=January 10, 2016}} Caught up in Murdock's conflict with Russian gangsters, she is kidnapped and beaten as the criminals search for him.{{cite web |url=https://www.ew.com/recap/daredevil-season-1-episode-4/2 |title=TV Recaps - ''Daredevil'': 'In the Blood' |work=Entertainment Weekly |first=Kevin P. |last=Sullivan |date=April 10, 2015 |access-date=January 10, 2016}} He saves Claire, and the two have a brief romantic encounter before she voices her concern that he may be becoming more and more like his enemies.{{cite web |url=https://www.ew.com/recap/daredevil-season-1-episode-5 |title=TV Recaps - ''Daredevil'': 'World on Fire' |work=Entertainment Weekly |first=Kevin P. |last=Sullivan |date=April 10, 2015 |access-date=January 10, 2016}} Realizing that his nighttime pursuits are an obstacle, they resume their previous dynamic of nurse and patient, as Claire continues to worry for him.{{cite web |url=https://www.ew.com/recap/daredevil-season-1-episode-11 |title=TV Recaps - ''Daredevil'': 'The Path of the Righteous' |work=Entertainment Weekly |first=Kevin P. |last=Sullivan |date=April 10, 2015 |access-date=January 10, 2016}} The character returns in [[Daredevil (season 2)|Season 2]].{{cite web |url=https://www.ew.com/article/2015/05/08/rosario-dawson-return-daredevil-season-2?iid=sr-link3 |title=Rosario Dawson returning for ''Daredevil'' season 2, may appear in other Netflix/Marvel shows |work=Entertainment Weekly |first=Jonathon |last=Dornbush |date=May 8, 2015 |access-date=January 10, 2016}} She helps Matt by secretly curing some teenagers who were held hostage and had their blood taken by the Hand.{{vague|date=March 2016}} After seeing that the teens were also brainwashed (as one of them killed his own father), the Hand ninjas arrive to reclaim them. During the encounter, a fellow nurse is killed and she knocks one of the ninja out of the window before she's knocked out herself and rescued by Daredevil. When the hospital plans to sweep it under the rug and is more concerned about its financial future than finding out what happened, she quits.{{cite episode|title=.380|series=Marvel's Daredevil|credits=Surjik, Stephen (director); Mark Verheiden (writer)|network=[[Netflix]]|airdate=March 18, 2016|season=2|number=11}} *Dawson reprised her role in the 2015 MCU series ''[[Jessica Jones (TV series)|Jessica Jones]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.etonline.com/news/169023_jessica_jones_showrunner_confirms_daredevil_crossover/ |title=''Jessica Jones'' Showrunner Teases a Super Suit for Krysten Ritter, Confirms ''Daredevil'' Crossover |last=Boone |first=John |work=[[Entertainment Tonight]] |date=July 30, 2015 |access-date=July 31, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150731195347/http://www.etonline.com/news/169023_jessica_jones_showrunner_confirms_daredevil_crossover/ |archive-date=July 31, 2015 |url-status=dead |df= }} In the episode "AKA Smile", Claire helps [[Jessica Jones]] when the "unbreakable" Luke Cage is seriously injured.{{cite web |url=https://www.ew.com/recap/marvel-s-jessica-jones-season-1-finale |title=Jessica Jones finale recap: 'AKA Smile' |work=Entertainment Weekly |first=Kevin P.|last=Sullivan |date=December 22, 2015 |access-date=January 10, 2016}} *Dawson also appears as Claire in the Netflix series ''[[Luke Cage (TV series)|Luke Cage]]''.{{cite web |url=https://www.ew.com/article/2015/09/02/luke-cage-theo-rossi-rosario-dawson-cast?iid=sr-link1 |title=Theo Rossi joins ''Luke Cage'' cast, Rosario Dawson will appear as Claire Temple |first=Jonathon |last=Dornbush |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=September 2, 2015 |access-date=January 10, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://marvel.com/news/tv/25106/netflix_original_series_marvels_luke_cage_adds_to_the_cast |title=Netflix Original Series ''Marvel's Luke Cage'' Adds to the Cast |publisher=[[Marvel.com]] |date=September 16, 2015|access-date=January 10, 2015}} According to Marvel, "Her blossoming friendship with Cage will have a major impact on both characters' lives."{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2015/09/luke-cage-marvel-misty-knight-shades-rafael-scarfe-claire-temple-1201530306/ |title=''Luke Cage'': Marvel Confirms Misty Knight, Shades, Rafael Scarfe & Claire Temple |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |first=Denise |last=Petski |date=September 16, 2015 |access-date=January 11, 2016}} After quitting her job following the events of ''Daredevil'' Season 2, she returns to her home in Harlem and reunites with her Latina mother, Soledad. She expresses a desire to help superhumans like Matt and Luke, and comes across Cage in one of the restaurants. She aids Cage in taking on the crime lord Diamondback and drives Luke to Georgia when he's critically injured by specialized bullets. She works together with Noah Burstein (who gave Luke his powers back at Seagate) to aid Luke in his recovery. At the end of the season, she and Luke express their love for each other, but Luke is taken back to Seagate before they can go on their first date. She is last seen interested in [[Colleen Wing]]'s martial arts training.{{cite episode|title=You Know My Steez|series=Marvel's Luke Cage|credits=Johnson, Clark (director); Aida Mashaka Croal & Cheo Hodari Coker (writer)|network=[[Netflix]]|airdate=September 30, 2016|season=1|number=13}} *Dawson reprised her role as Claire Temple in the TV series ''[[Iron Fist (TV series)|Iron Fist]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbr.com/nycc-iron-fist-cast-makes-first-ever-live-appearance/ |title=NYCC: Iron Fist Cast Makes First-Ever Live Appearance |last=Damore |first=Meagan |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |date=October 8, 2016 |access-date=October 9, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009182639/http://www.cbr.com/nycc-iron-fist-cast-makes-first-ever-live-appearance/ |archive-date=October 9, 2016 |url-status=dead |df= }} She allies with Iron Fist and becomes a student at Colleen Wing's dojo. *Dawson also reprised her role as Claire Temple in the miniseries ''[[The Defenders (miniseries)|The Defenders]]''.{{cite web | url=https://www.comingsoon.net/tv/news/782357-scott-glenn-rachael-taylor-and-rosario-dawson-confirmed-for-the-defenders#/slide/1 | title=Scott Glenn, Rachael Taylor, and Rosario Dawson Confirmed for The Defenders | publisher=Comingsoon.net | date=November 2, 2016 | access-date=November 2, 2016 | last=Perry | first=Spencer }} ===Video games=== *Claire Temple appears as a playable character in ''[[Marvel Avengers Academy]]'',{{cite web|url=https://www.bleedingcool.com/2017/08/17/avengers-academy-defenders/|title=Not To Be Outdone, Avengers Academy Brings The Defenders To The Palm Of Your Hand|last=Glass|first=Joe|website=Bleeding Cool News|date=August 17, 2017|access-date=October 15, 2017}} voiced by Tiana Camacho.{{cite web|url=https://www.tianacamacho.com/resume|title=tianacamacho | Resume|website=tianacamacho.com|access-date=October 18, 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Short description|Fictional character in the Marvel Cinematic Universe}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox character | color = #AF181F | name = Claire Temple | series = {{no italics|[[Marvel Cinematic Universe]]}} | image = Rosario Dawson as Claire Temple.png | caption = Rosario Dawson as Claire Temple in ''Daredevil'' | based_on = {{Indented plainlist| * {{Based on|[[Claire Temple]]|[[Archie Goodwin (comics)|Archie Goodwin]]|{{quad}}[[George Tuska]]}} * {{Based on|[[Night Nurse (comics)|Night Nurse]]|Jean Thomas|{{quad}}Win Mortimer}} }} | first = '''''[[Daredevil (TV series)|Daredevil]]''''':
"[[Cut Man (Daredevil)|Cut Man]]" (2015) | last = '''''[[Luke Cage (TV series)|Luke Cage]]''''':
"[[Wig Out (Luke Cage)|Wig Out]]" (2018) | adapted_by = [[Drew Goddard]] | portrayer = [[Rosario Dawson]] | occupation = Nurse | family = Soledad Temple (mother) | nationality = American | significant_other = [[Luke Cage (Marvel Cinematic Universe)|Luke Cage]] }} '''Claire Temple''' is a [[character (arts)|character]] portrayed by [[Rosario Dawson]] in several of the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]] (MCU) television series, based on the [[Marvel Comics]] characters [[Claire Temple]] and [[Night Nurse (comics)|Night Nurse]]. A nurse who gives medical aid to vigilantes, she was created for the [[Daredevil (season 1)|first season]] of ''[[Daredevil (TV series)|Daredevil]]'' (2015). Dawson then signed a deal to return for the [[Daredevil (season 2)|second season]] of the series (2016), as well as potentially appear in any other [[List of Marvel Cinematic Universe television series#Netflix series|Marvel Netflix series]]. She has since reprised the role in ''[[Jessica Jones (TV series)|Jessica Jones]]'' (2015), ''[[Luke Cage (TV series)|Luke Cage]]'' (2016–2018), ''[[Iron Fist (TV series)|Iron Fist]]'' (2017–2018), and ''[[The Defenders (miniseries)|The Defenders]]'' (2017). The character has also appeared in a [[Marvel Cinematic Universe tie-in comics#Marvel's Jessica Jones (2015)|''Jessica Jones'' tie-in comic]] (2015). == Marvel Cinematic Universe == === Television series === {{further|Daredevil (TV series)|Jessica Jones (TV series)|Luke Cage (TV series)|Iron Fist (TV series)|The Defenders (miniseries)}} After discovering [[Matt Murdock (Marvel Cinematic Universe)|Matt Murdock / Daredevil]] beaten in a dumpster in the first season of ''Daredevil'', nurse Claire Temple gives him aid.{{Cite episode |title=Cut Man |episode-link=Cut Man (Daredevil) |series=Marvel's Daredevil |network=[[Netflix]] |date=April 10, 2015 |season=1 |number=2 |credits=Abraham, Phil (director); Drew Goddard (writer)}} She is kidnapped by the mafia for this, as bait for Daredevil, and though he is able to save her,{{Cite episode |title=In the Blood |episode-link=In the Blood (Daredevil) |series=Marvel's Daredevil |network=[[Netflix]] |date=April 10, 2015 |season=1 |number=4 |credits=Girotti, Ken (director); Joe Pokaski (writer)}} they mutually decide that it is too dangerous to become involved, in spite of the spark between them. Claire does continue to give him medical aid as needed, while Murdock occasionally uses her position at Metro-General Hospital to his advantage.{{Cite episode |title=The Path of the Righteous |episode-link=The Path of the Righteous |series=Marvel's Daredevil |network=[[Netflix]] |date=April 10, 2015 |season=1 |number=11 |credits=Gomez, Nick (director); Steven S. DeKnight and Douglas Petrie (writer)}} In ''Jessica Jones'', Temple is on duty at the hospital when a seriously injured [[Luke Cage (Marvel Cinematic Universe)|Luke Cage]] is brought in; Temple takes care of Cage for [[Jessica Jones (Marvel Cinematic Universe)|Jessica Jones]].{{Cite episode |title=AKA Smile |episode-link=AKA Smile |series=Marvel's Jessica Jones |network=[[Netflix]] |date=November 20, 2015 |season=1 |number=13 |credits=Rymer, Michael (director); Scott Reynolds & Melissa Rosenberg (story); Jamie King & Scott Reynolds (writer)}} In the [[Daredevil (season 2)|second season of ''Daredevil'']], Temple quits her job at the hospital, when it tries to cover up the death of her coworker following an attack by [[The Hand (comics)#Television|The Hand]], and leaves [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]];{{Cite episode |title=.380 |episode-link=.380 (Daredevil) |series=Marvel's Daredevil |network=[[Netflix]] |date=March 18, 2016 |season=2 |number=11 |credits=Surjik, Stephen (director); Mark Verheiden (writer)}} she arrives in [[Harlem]], where her mother runs a diner, in ''Luke Cage''. Temple reconnects with Cage there, and helps him defend the neighborhood.{{Cite episode |title=Just to Get a Rep |episode-link=Just to Get a Rep (Luke Cage) |series=Marvel's Luke Cage |network=[[Netflix]] |date=September 30, 2016 |season=1 |number=5 |credits=Jobst, Marc (director); Jason Horwitch (writer)}} She falls for Cage, but before they can act on their feelings he is arrested.{{Cite episode |title=You Know My Steez |episode-link=You Know My Steez (Luke Cage) |series=Marvel's Luke Cage |network=[[Netflix]] |date=September 30, 2016 |season=1 |number=13 |credits=Johnson, Clark (director); Aida Mashaka Croal & Cheo Hodari Coker (writer)}} Temple begins taking lessons at [[Colleen Wing (Marvel Cinematic Universe)|Colleen Wing]]'s dojo, through whom she meets [[Danny Rand (Marvel Cinematic Universe)|Danny Rand]] in ''Iron Fist''.{{Cite episode |title=Under Leaf Pluck Lotus |episode-link=Under Leaf Pluck Lotus |series=Marvel's Iron Fist |network=[[Netflix]] |date=March 17, 2017 |season=1 |number=5 |credits=Briesewitz, Uta (director); Cristine Chambers (writer)}} Temple helps Rand in his fight against The Hand.{{Cite episode |title=Dragon Plays with Fire |episode-link=Dragon Plays with Fire |series=Marvel's Iron Fist |network=[[Netflix]] |date=March 17, 2017 |season=1 |number=13 |credits=Surjik, Stephen (director); Scott Buck, Tamara Becher-Wilkinson and Pat Charles (writer)}} In ''The Defenders'', Temple is reunited with Cage, who is let out of jail early thanks to Foggy Nelson, and resumes a relationship with him.{{Cite episode |title=The H Word |episode-link=The H Word |series=The Defenders |network=[[Netflix]] |date=August 18, 2017 |season=1 |number=1 |credits=Clarkson, S.J. (director); Douglas Petrie & Marco Ramirez (writer)}} She then introduces Cage to Rand.{{Cite episode |title=Worst Behavior |episode-link=Worst Behavior (The Defenders) |series=The Defenders |network=[[Netflix]] |date=August 18, 2017 |season=1 |number=3 |credits=Hoar, Peter (director); Lauren Schmidt Hissrich & Douglas Petrie (writer)}} In the second season of ''Luke Cage'', Temple continues her relationship with Cage, but suddenly grows cautious of his personal issues, particularly with his father and the way he handles justice.{{Cite episode |title=Straighten It Out |episode-link=Straighten It Out (Luke Cage) |series=Marvel's Luke Cage |network=[[Netflix]] |date=June 22, 2018 |season=2 |number=2 |credits=Green, Steph (director); Akela Cooper (writer)}} After an argument, Temple asks that they "take a break" from each other.{{Cite episode |title=Wig Out |episode-link=Wig Out (Luke Cage) |series=Marvel's Luke Cage |network=[[Netflix]] |date=June 22, 2018 |season=2 |number=3 |credits=Jobst, Marc (director); Matt Owens (writer)}} By the end of the season, Cage has completely moved on from Temple who tries to enter Harlem's Paradise to see him, but is turned away.{{Cite episode |title=They Reminisce Over You |episode-link=They Reminisce Over You (Luke Cage) |series=Marvel's Luke Cage |network=[[Netflix]] |date=June 22, 2018 |season=2 |number=13 |credits=Lopez, Alex Garcia (director); Cheo Hodari Coker (writer)}} === Tie-in comic === {{further|Marvel Cinematic Universe tie-in comics}} Temple appears in the ''Jessica Jones'' tie-in comic, serving as [[Turk Barrett#In other media|Turk Barrett]]'s nurse. == Concept and creation == [[Rosario Dawson]] joined the cast of ''Daredevil'' in June 2014, and her role was revealed to be that of Temple in October of that year. The MCU character is an amalgam of the comic characters [[Claire Temple]] and [[Night Nurse (comics)|Night Nurse]], with ''Daredevil'' [[showrunner]] [[Steven S. DeKnight]] noting that the character was originally "going to be the actual Night Nurse from the comics ... we had her name in a script and it came back that it was possible [[[Marvel Studios|the feature side]]] were going to use her" and "had plans for her down the road," necessitating the change to using the more obscure comics character Claire Temple as her name. {{Quote box|quote=We wanted to have an opportunity to be able to let the audience know that this person knows this person, and that means they know that person. I think if you play the game out, you can sort of see ... how important that character's going to be.|source=—Jeph Loeb on Temple appearing across multiple Marvel/Netflix series|width=33%|align=right}} In May 2015, Dawson signed with Marvel to return for the second season of ''Daredevil'' as part of an "exclusive TV deal" that also allows her to appear in any other [[List of Marvel Cinematic Universe television series#Netflix series|Marvel/Netflix series]]. Dawson explained that she signs on with Marvel for a year at a time, for a certain number of episodes, and finds out which series the episodes are for closer to the time of filming. In July, ''Jessica Jones'' showrunner [[Melissa Rosenberg]] revealed that Dawson would be "dropping in", with Dawson making a guest appearance in the [[Jessica Jones (season 1)#ep13|season finale]]. Before ''Jessica Jones'' debuted that November, a tie-in comic prequel was released featuring several ''Daredevil'' and ''Jessica Jones'' characters, including Temple, to explore "the connective tissue that will build between the series". Marvel announced in September 2015 that Dawson would be appearing in ''Luke Cage'', in what Cage actor [[Mike Colter]] described as a "significant part", noting that the comics character Claire Temple was introduced as a love interest for Cage. The series introduces Temple's mother (portrayed by [[Sônia Braga]]), and gives Claire "a large storyline ... [she helps] out a lot." It also references her role as a version of Night Nurse, with [[Sean Ringgold]]'s character Sugar dismissively referring to her as "the night nurse". Explaining the decision to have Temple appear across multiple series, which has been compared to the role that [[Nick Fury (Marvel Cinematic Universe)|Nick Fury]] plays as "the connective thread" between the [[List of Marvel Cinematic Universe films|MCU films]], Marvel Television head [[Jeph Loeb]] explained that it was due to Dawson's performance, saying "It wasn't just that Claire fit so well in those worlds, it's that Rosario fit so well in those worlds." When Temple first appears in the second season of ''Daredevil'', she has "a cut in her eyebrow", which Daredevil actor [[Charlie Cox]] explained was from one of the other series, saying that "the timeline had been thought through and worked out" to connect Dawson's various performances. In July 2016, Dawson was unable to promote ''Luke Cage'' because she was "back in New York ... filming something else for Marvel TV", which was confirmed that October to be ''[[Iron Fist (TV series)|Iron Fist]]''; this appearance was set up at the end of ''Luke Cage''. A month later, Dawson was revealed to also be reprising her role in the crossover miniseries ''[[The Defenders (miniseries)|The Defenders]]''. Dawson also expressed interest in making a [[cameo appearance]] in ''[[The Punisher (TV series)|The Punisher]]'', a spin-off series from ''Daredevil'', but was unable to due to a scheduling conflict. {{Quote box|quote=I wanted it to really honor this journey I’ve had with her, and what she’s been and what she’s stood for, and what she means to a lot of people ... because [she shows that] you don’t have to have special superpowers to make a difference and an impact in your community and to challenge yourself to grow and to be greater. She just really inspired me a lot.|source=Rosario Dawson on her final scene portraying Temple in the second season of ''Luke Cage''|width=33%|align=left}} After appearing in the [[Luke Cage (season 2)|second season]] of ''Luke Cage'', Dawson explained that she was reluctant to continue making appearances in the many series due to having to travel away from her family when working on the New York sets. She did think that she would return to ''Luke Cage'' if it was renewed for further seasons, and again expressed interest in appearing in ''The Punisher'' at some point moving forward "just so I can feel like I’ve done every show". Dawson later revealed that she had asked ''Luke Cage'' showrunner [[Cheo Hodari Coker]] whether she could contribute to the writing of Temple's last scene in the season; she considered the scene to be the culmination of three years of work for her, and felt that it had initially been written too much from the perspective of Cage, whom Temple has a fight with in the scene that ends their relationship. Dawson praised Coker for allowing her to push the scene to feature more of an equal balance between the characters, and Coker praised the work she did on this. {{clear left}} == Characterization == Dawson said in April 2015, "she's someone who also throws herself into the fray and had made it her life mission to help, even if that means risking her own life ... My character is a stand-in for the audience. She’s not a love interest—she’s this skeptical eye looking at this strange situation." On the relationship between Temple and Murdock in ''Daredevil'', Dawson said, "The show explores how necessary it is for two people to finally have their masks off with each other. For Matt Murdock, this is the first person he has that’s going to be able to see that transition for him ... But she gets confronted with the question: How far will you go? What does it mean if you’re helping someone who is maybe going to hurt other people?" Dawson felt that the character resonated with audiences, and was brought back for more series, because, "She's funny, she's wry, she's strong—she's built for that world, because she's great under pressure. She's someone—hero or not—you'd want to have in a dire situation... I really just liked her arc all the way through." After the character is shown using fighting in ''Daredevil'', Dawson explained, "her eyes have been opened up to this other world—and she's crossed the line. You know, this is someone who helps people, and she's been violent now but seeing the need for it. I think there's a lot that she's having to grapple with". Discussing Temple's relationship with Cage in ''Luke Cage'', Colter said that "she will deal with me in a different way than she dealt with Matt Murdock. Matt Murdock's character's completely different from mine. Because she plays a nurse that basically seems to be in the right place at the right time, and she's very good at helping out superheroes who are in need ... I think she's going to be a very good companion for Luke. I think she's someone that Luke needs in his life at this time." ==See also== *[[Characters of the Marvel Cinematic Universe]] == References == {{reflist|refs= {{Cite web |url=http://marvel.com/news/tv/2014/6/20/22725/rosario_dawson_joins_marvels_daredevil_for_netflix |title=Rosario Dawson Joins Marvel's Daredevil For Netflix |date=June 20, 2014 |website=[[Marvel Comics|Marvel.com]] |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140905195945/http://marvel.com/news/tv/2014/6/20/22725/rosario_dawson_joins_marvels_daredevil_for_netflix |archive-date=September 5, 2014 |access-date=June 20, 2014}} {{Cite web |url=http://www.newsarama.com/22408-nycc-2014-marvel-s-daredevil-on-netflix-panel-live.html |title=NYCC 2014: Marvel's DAREDEVIL on Netflix Panel LIVE!
